Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28*, a custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and when such modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

ch. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The Plaintiff, **Jessica Turner**, residing in Norfolk County, Massachusetts, respectfully brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28; ch. 209C, § 20; and ch. 215, § 6*, seeking a modification of the existing custody and parenting order entered by this Honorable Court on **May 15, 2020**.

ch. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Plaintiff, **Jessica Turner**, residing in Norfolk County, Massachusetts, respectfully brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28; ch. 209C, § 20; and ch. 215, § 6*, seeking a modification of the existing custody and parenting order entered by this Honorable Court on **May 15, 2020**.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case does discuss the standard for modification—requiring a material change in circumstances—but it focuses on financial changes in the payor spouse’s income, earning capacity, and assets, not on changes in a parent’s availability or stability for the children. The court ultimately holds that there was no sufficient change in circumstances to warrant modification, and there is no language about Massachusetts courts consistently modifying orders based on significant changes in parental availability or stability. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … However, while a substantial decrease in income or financial status may warrant a modification, such a decrease does not alone compel a modification.”

Buker v. Buker, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 845 (19.raw_text: Buker v. Buker, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 845 (1980)
Buker v. Buker, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 845 (19.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Buker v. Buker, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 845 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether an alimony order may be modified within a contempt proceeding absent a showing of changed circumstances; it does not involve child custody, parenting time, or changes in parental availability and stability for children. While it acknowledges that ‘changed circumstances’ are generally required to modify alimony, it does not articulate any rule about modification based on significant changes in a parent’s circumstances affecting children. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Buker v. Buker, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 845 (19.relevant_excerpt: [T]he trial judge entered a reservation and report… raising a question… whether a judgment ordering the payment of alimony may be modified in the context of a contempt proceeding in the absence of a showing of changed circumstances such as have repeatedly been held requisite for modification of an alimony judgment in the context of a proceeding for modification commenced under G. L. c. 208, § 37. 1. To speed the future course of this case, we answer that question in the negative…

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion is not a modification case and does not discuss changes in a parent’s circumstances as the basis for modifying an existing custody or visitation order. Rather, it sets out the standard for an initial removal decision in the context of a divorce, focusing on the “real advantage” test and best interests at the time of the original judgment. It therefore does not stand for the asserted proposition that Massachusetts courts have consistently held that significant changes in parental circumstances warrant modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)…”

D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991).raw_text: D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991)
D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991).case_name: Chief of the Fire Department v. Allard
D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991).support_reasoning: This opinion has nothing to do with child custody, parental circumstances, or modification standards. It deals solely with enforcement of a fire code sprinkler statute, the effect of a subsequent statutory amendment, and principles governing prospective equitable relief. It therefore does not address, let alone establish, any rule about modification based on significant changes in a parent’s circumstances or availability and stability for children.
D. v. C., 30 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1991).relevant_excerpt: "When the fire chief sought to enforce compliance with § 26H through the injunctive process, he was invoking the equitable powers of the court and seeking prospective relief. Unlike legal proceedings, which typically determine a defendant’s compliance with obligations on a date in the past, equitable proceedings, looking to prospective relief, take note of events occurring after the commencement of the action..."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the statutory requirement of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” for modifying custody, but it does not state or affirm that such changes—especially those affecting availability and stability—warrant modification. Instead, the court holds that the purported changes (including the mother’s relocation and work schedule) did NOT warrant modification and reverses the custody change. Thus, the case limits when modifications are appropriate rather than standing for the broad, affirmative proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about initial custody determinations under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not about modification standards or when a ‘significant change in circumstances’ warrants modification. The court explicitly declines to apply or discuss the substantial-change standard under § 20 and instead treats the case as tried under the initial-custody framework. It therefore does not establish or affirm any principle that Massachusetts courts consistently modify custody upon a significant change in a parent’s availability or stability.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns choosing between two adoptive placements after parents have already been found unfit; it does not discuss modification of prior custody or adoption orders based on a later significant change in a parent’s circumstances. The court focuses on best interests, deference to trial judges, and weighing competing adoption plans, not on how parental changes in availability or stability justify modifying an existing order. Thus it does not establish or affirm the proposition about modification standards tied to changed parental circumstances.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’"

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings on the effects of domestic violence, not about post‑judgment modification standards or changed circumstances. It does not discuss what constitutes a “significant change in circumstances” or when such changes warrant modification of an existing custody order. Therefore it does not establish or affirm the proposition that significant changes in a parent’s availability or stability warrant modification, nor does it address that doctrinal issue at all.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s circumstances—especially those affecting availability and stability for children—warrants modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and the best-interest factors a judge may weigh, including stability, work schedules, and a parent’s willingness to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. It does not, however, address the separate legal standard for modification of an existing custody order based on a ‘significant change in circumstances.’ The case is about an initial custody determination in the context of dissolving a domestic partnership, not about modification, so it does not stand for the proposition that changed parental circumstances warrant modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”
